lessons.title: Mhoro, Shamwari! - Hello, Friend!
lessons.description: Learn basic greetings and how to introduce yourself in Shona culture
learningObjectives: Master basic Shona greetings (mhoro, mhoroi, hesi)
Understand the cultural importance of respectful greetings
Practice proper pronunciation with audio feedback
Learn to introduce yourself with confidence
discoveryElements: Explore different times of day greetings
Discover the difference between formal and informal greetings
Learn about the plural of respect in Shona culture
culturalNotes: In Shona culture, greetings are sacred and show respect
Always use plural forms when addressing elders or strangers
The greeting 'mhoroi' shows more respect than 'mhoro'
Proper greetings create harmony and show good upbringing

vocabulary.usage: Used with friends and people your age
Used with elders, strangers, or to show respect
Respectful way to ask how someone is
vocabulary.culturalContext: Shows genuine concern for someone's wellbeing

vocabulary.usage: Casual way to ask how someone is

exercises.question: When should you use 'mhoroi' instead of 'mhoro'?
exercises.correctAnswer: When greeting elders or showing respect
options: When greeting elders or showing respect
exercises.culturalExplanation: Mhoroi shows greater respect and is used with elders, strangers, or in formal situations

lessons.title: Ini Ndinonzi - My Name Is
lessons.description: Learn to introduce yourself and exchange names in Shona
learningObjectives: Learn to state your name in Shona
Practice numbers 1-10 for counting and market use
discoveryElements: Explore how names carry meaning in Shona culture
Discover the importance of knowing someone's name
Learn about traditional Shona naming practices
culturalNotes: Names in Shona culture often have deep meaning
It's polite to ask for someone's name after greeting
Numbers are essential for market interactions
Knowing someone's name creates a personal connection

vocabulary.culturalContext: Names carry deep meaning and family history
Formal way to state your name

vocabulary.usage: Respectful way to ask someone's name
vocabulary.culturalContext: Shows respect when asking someone's name

exercises.question: Practice saying 'munonzi ani' (what is your name)

assessments.title: Basic Vocabulary Assessment
assessments.description: Test your knowledge of basic Shona vocabulary
instructions: You have 15 minutes to complete this assessment

questions.question: What does "mangwanani" mean?
questions.explanation: Mangwanani is the traditional Shona greeting for morning.

questions.question: What is the Shona word for "water"?

assessments.title: Basic Grammar Assessment
assessments.description: Test your understanding of basic Shona grammar
instructions: Complete each sentence with the correct word
You have 20 minutes to complete this assessment

questions.question: Complete: "Ndiri kuenda ___ Harare" (I am going to Harare)
questions.explanation: Kuna is used to indicate direction or destination.
